description: Masked cowboys take center stage this issue, starting off with cover feature Redmask in “Redmask vs. Strawman, illustrated by Frank Bolle. Then, The Haunted Horseman (comic’s first Ghost Rider) learns “The Horror of Dead Man’s Cave!!”, by Ray Krank and Dick Ayers; followed by The Durango Kid in “Strong Medicine”, with art by Fred Guardineer, and The Masked Rider in “Unsolved Mystery”. Plus, there are two full stories starring a couple of hombres who are NOT afraid to show their faces, Rocky Lane in “The Frame-Up”; drawn by Tom Cooke, and Tom Mix and “The Mortgage on Murder”, with art by Carl Pfeufer & John Jordan. Western comics adventure at it’s best, straight out of the genre’s Golden Age, the early 1950′s. 40 pages, black & white with color covers. Standard Best of the West size & format, saddle-stitched.

Old West comic book action at it’s best, with six great features, as always, reprinted from actual, vintage comic books of the genre’s heyday, the Golden Age of cowboy comics- the 1950′s. Of course, the BOW “Big Three” are all here- cover feature The Haunted Horseman in “The Man Who Hated”, as drawn by Dick Ayers; Frank Bolle’s Redmask in “The Man Who Rescued Redmask”; and The Durango Kid in “The Big Hunt”, illustrated by Fred Guardineer. Then, it’s more favorites like Rocky Lane in “The Devil’s Hoof”, drawn by Tom Cooke, and Black Diamond in “Comanche War Drums”. Rod Cameron makes his Best of the West debut this issue in a story entitled “The Human Shield”, with art by Clem Weisbecker, plus a Pistol Packin’ Pattie short, and an inside cover photo of Charles Starrett and Tris Coffin. 44 pages, black & white interiors with color covers. Standard comic book size, saddle-stitched.

Saddle up for Wild West action with the best vintage Western comic book reprints anywhere!! Just inside a stunning Bob Lubbers-drawn FIREHAIR cover, ( backed by a tryptych of cool 1950 cowboy move stills) you’ll get The Durango Kid in “Terror in the Timber:, as rendered by Fred Guardineer. Then, Dick Ayer’s original ghost rider, The Haunted Horseman faces off against- “He Who Laughs!!” The Latigo Kid, as drawn by Joe Maneely, tries to avoid joining “The Necktie Party”; then cover feature Firehair must run off Snakeoil Sam in a Lee Elias classic stright from Rangers Comics of the late 1940′s. Nexr, Red Mask (with the help of his artist, Frank Bolle takes on “The Diggers”, and finally, Dick Ayers has an encore, as the delineator of Jolly Jim Dandy, in a story reprinted from Dan’l Boone #1. Reprints of actual vintage Western comic book stories, originally published by Magazine Enterprises, Fiction House and others.Black & white with color covers; 44 pages, standard comic book size. span>

All your favorite vintage Western features are back this issue, plus some exciting newcomers to the BOW fold!! The Durango Kid tussles with Carton & his cattle rustlers in “Show ‘Em No Mercy”, drawn by Joe Certa & John Belfi; while Redmask performs in “Terror’s Theatre”, written by Gardner Fox and illustrated by Frank Bolle; Dick Ayers & The Haunted Horseman return in “The Scarecrow Sheriff”, and Lash LaRue gets the spotlight in “The Silent Watch”, amongst our regular cast of classic reprint features. Then come the special guests- the art of the great Joe Maneely graces The Latigo Kid in “Riot At The Rodeo”; and pretty Kitty Carson , the ruff ridn’ gal sheriff chimes in, ably rendered by another stellar creator, Bob Powell, in “Stagecoach Murders”. Finally, it’s a Rocke Mastroserio-drawn short, Buffalo Bill Cody. Just like every issue, it’s Western thrills aplently reprinted from the Golden Age of the Western comic book, the 1950′s, as we re-present classic comic book stories originally published by Magazine Enterprises, Fawcett, Chalton & others, using state-of-the-art reproduction techniques. Best of the West is 44 pages, standard comic book size & format, black & white with color covers, saddle stiched.

Special MONTE HALE tribute issue!! As a tribute to the last of the great movie cowboys, MONTE HALE is in the spotlight this issue, as star of the stunning color cover and in two interior stories; “Safe-Crackers Unlimited” (drawn by Ed Good ) and an untitled lead story, illustrated by the great Gil Kane. In addition, there is a special guest-editorial in the form of a heartfelt tribute to Monte from fan Bill Durham. But that’s not all, as all of your regular BOW favorites are here, too- The HAUNTED HORSEMAN in “The Return of Magico”; as drawn by the master, Dick Ayere; RED MASK in “The Weapons of Redmask” by Frank Bolle; and Durango Kid in “Two-Gun Tot”, with art by Fred Guardineer. As always, it’s the best in vintage Western comic book reprints; full stories flawlessly reproduced. 44 pages, black & white with color covers; 10″ X 6″ comic book format, saddle stitched.

Western comic book action at it’s finest!! We start off this issue with a brand-new cover piece by the great Alan Weiss- featuring an awesome rendition of The HAUNTED HORSEMAN- who then leads off the leather-slappin’ action inside with an untitled story that pits HH against deadly Kiowa raiders in a tale written by Gardner Fox and illustrated by Dick Ayers. Then, it’s the masked avenger from Prize Comics; The BLACK BULL, in “Was On The Range”, with spectacular art by Will Elder & John Severin. The DURANGO KID chimes in with “The Death I Almost Died”, with art by Joe Certa & John Belfi; followed by Frank Bolle’s RED MASK in “The Unknown Treasure”; The LONE RIDER (drawn by Ken Battefield ) in “Big Trouble”; a return engagement by John Severin drawing WYATT EARP in “Ghost Town’, AND a personal letter from cowboy movie great MONTE HALE and news of the new Monte Hale website. Great classic cowboy comics reprints from Magazine Enterprises, Prixe, Ajax-Farrell and Charlton, all crisp, clean & perfect. 44 pages, black & white with color covers, saddle-stitched. Standard Best of the West size, printed in 2007.

More high-quality Western comic book action, starting with Tim Holt as REDMASK in “Robbersw Roost”, drawn by Frank Bolle, and guest-starring Wild Bill Hickok and Bat Masterson. , from Tim Holt #28, 1952. Then, it’s MONTE HALE in “The Stolen Six-Gun”, with art by Max Elkan, from Monte Hale Western #75, 1952; followed by The HAUNTED HORSEMAN in “The Shadow Slayers”, from Tim Holt #33. The DURANGO KID runs afoul of the “Code of the Drygulcher”, drawn by Fred Guardineer, aqnd finally a newcomer- from the vintage comic books of Australia its The LONE AVENGER in “Swamp Girl”, with art & story by Len Lawson, from Australia’s Action Comics # 20. Great “shoot-em-up” adventure from M.E., Fawcett and other defunct publishers. 44 pages, black & white with color covers- standard comic book size, saddle stitched.

The MASKED RIDER is our lead and cover feature this issue, startin’ off the stampede of Wild West comic book action in a tale titled “Tightrope of Fear”, drawn by Pete Morisi. Then, crack artist Joe Certa provides the illustration for a DURANGO KID opus called “Crooked Irons”, originally seen in M. E.’s Durango Kid #3. TIM HOLT as Redmask appears, courtesy of Frank Bolle, in a 1952 drama, “The Sheriff of Silver Creek”, from Tim Holt #32. MONTE HALE rides through with “The Highjacked Herd”, with art by Bob Laughlin, as originally seen in Fawcett’s Monte Hale Western; and The HAUNTED HORSEMAN stars in the enigmatically- titled “Assignment: Hanted Horseman”, drawn as always by the great Dick Ayers. (Originally published in Ghost Rider #11, 1953.) All these great full-story vintage reprints, plus full-page repros of TWO great John Severin-drawn covers for Prize Comics Western, and inside cover photo stills featuring Charles Starrett from two Durango Kid films; “Both Barrels Blazing” and “West of Dodge City”. 44 pages, black & white with color covers, standard comic book size and format, saddle stitched.

Another cornucopia of cowboy classics reprinted from the best Western comic books of the 1950′s. Features include REDMASK in “Stage To Devil’s Gap”, drawn by Frank Bolle, originally printed in M. E.’s Redmask #45; WILD BILL PECOS in “The Two-Gun Grandpappies”, as illustrated by John Buscema, originally seen in Orbit Pubs’ Wild Bill Pecos The Westerner magazine. Then, it’s MASKED RIDER, in “Caged Eagle”, with art by Pete Morisi; DURANGO KID in “Law of the Hangman’s Noose”, by Joe Certa & John Belfi, MONTE HALE in “The Outlaws’ Camel Cavalcade”, drawn by Carl Pfeufer and Bob Laughlin, and finally Dick Ayers’ HAUNTED HORSEMAN in “The Invisible Death”. 44 pages, black & white interiors with color covers; standard comic book size, saddle-stitched. As always, the highest-quality vintage Western comic book reprints anywhere!!

Two-fisted Western action aplenty this issue, as per usual, with the finest full-story reprints from the heyday of the cowboy genre in comic books, as originally published by Fawcett, Magazine Enterprises and others. Lead off with Frank Bolle’s REDMASK in “Tim Holt VS. Redmask”, followed by MONTE HALE in “Diamond Deadfall”, drawn by Ed Good. Then, see Norman Maurer’s rendition of WYATT EARP in “Navajo Uprising”; followed by a DURANGO KID classic as rendered by Fred Guardineer; “The Phantom Badhat”. Then, from Lev Gleason’s Black Diamond Western, see BLACK DIAMOND himself in “The Wrong Killers”, drawn by Myron Fass, and Dick Ayer’s HAUNTED HORSEMAN in “The Man From Scotland Yard”. Plus- inside cover photo stills of Charles Starrett as THE DURANGO KID. Black & white with color covers, 44 pages, standard Best of the West size, saddle-stitch bound.

The finest issue yet, full to bursting with SIX great full-length vintage Western comic bookmstories from the 1950′s !! This issue presents The DURANGO KID in “The Vengence Trail”, as drawn by Joe Certa & John Belfi; Dick Ayer’s Haunted Horseman in “The Murdering Mine”; MONTE HALE starring in “The Killers of Cayungo”, drawn by Ed Good; The WHIP in “Dead Shot”; ANNIE OAKLEY (as illustrated by Ross Andru) in “Wanted: Dead or Alive”; and REDMASK in “Hell’s Hideout”, illustrated by Frank Bolle. The 1950′s best cowboy comics, as originally found in comic books published by Magazine Enterprises, Fawcett, Quality and others, reproduced using the height of color dropping technology. 44 pages, black & white with color covers, standard comic book size, saddle- stitched.

Another full volume of pistol-packing prairie prowlers, including REDMASK in “The Return Of The Black Phantom!”, drawn by Frank Bolle, from Tim Holt #38; The DURANGO KID in “Smart Hombres Die Dumb!”, illustrated by Joe Certa and John Belfi; MONTE HALE in “The Costly Bargain”, from Monte Hale Western #82; BLACK DIAMOND in “Hired Gun”, drawn by Myron Fass, from Black Diamond Western; Dick Ayer’s HAUNTED HORSEMAN in “The Mad Commander”; and ROCKY LANE in “Burning Gold”, with art by Charles Nicholas and Sal Trapani. All vintage classics reproduced with crystal clarity, just as they appeared four and five decades ago within the pages of comic books published by Magazine Enterprises, Lev Gleason, Fawcett and Charlton Comics. Standard comic book size, saddle-stitched, black & white interiors with color covers.

The best issue yet!! 6 full classic Western comic book story reprints from the top publishers of the cowboy theme during it’s heyday of the 1940′s-1950′s. Cover features REDMASK opens the all-out action with “The False Alarm Crimes”, as drawn by Frank Bolle, originally seen in Magazine Enterprises’ Best of the West #12 (original series). Then it’s M. E.’s original ghost rider, THE HAUNTED HORSEMAN in “Death By Flame”, as originally presented in Tim Holt #22; followed by “Durango’s Stolen Steed”, a DURANGO KID adventure illustrated by Joe Certa and John Belfi. Prize Comic’s BLACK BULL makes in appearance, in “One-Man Posse”, from Prize Western #85- beautifully illustrated by John Severin and Will Elder. The LEMONADE KID takes to the trail in “No Locks To Murder”, drawn by Bob Powell, from an issue of Bobby Benson’s B-Bar-B Riders; and finally a rollicking romp with KITTY CARSON, the ruff-ridin’ gal sheriff, as she deals with “Indian Revenge”, also illustrated by Bob Powell. An Ed Good MONTE HALE short, “Goodbye Old Paint”, and movie stills from “The Desert Horseman”, “Ghost of Zorro”, “Desert Vigilante”, “Death Valley Gunfighter”, “California Firebrand”, and “Bells of San Angelo” round out the issue. 44 pages, black & white with color covers. Standard comic book size, saddle-sdtitched.

NOW WITH MORE PAGES OF GREAT VINTAGE WESTERN COMICS ACTION!!! This issue leads off with Frank Bolle’s TIM HOLT in “Cave of Three Skeletons”!!, originally presented in Magazine Enterprises’ Tim Holt #22, in 1951. Then, it’s cover star The HAUNTED HORSEMAN, in a Dick Ayers tour-de-force from Ghost Rider #9, 1952: “The Left Boot Murders!!” Next, Quality Comics’ The WHIP makes an appearance, in a previouisly unreprinted ( and untitled ) story from a late-1940′s issue of Crack Comics. Al Williamson (under his “Baldo Smudge” penname) contributes a beautiful WILD BILL HICKOK short, “Silver Colt”; and Jay Scott Pike & writer Robert Bernstein are behind “The Day The Earth Cracked”, a DARK RIDER adventure. Movie star cowboty MONTE HALE rings in with “The Tragic Lesson”, with art supplied by Ed Good; ROCKY LANE appears in “Invitation To Hang”, and The DURANGO KID stars in “Trouble Never Ends”, a Joe Certa/John Belfi-drawn story from The Durango Kid #17. Plus- inside and back-cover photos of Charles Starret and Rocky Lane. Vintage comic book reprints in clear, crisp black & white, behind full color covers. 48 pages, standard comic book sixe, saddle-stitched.

Now with even MORE PAGES of Western comics action; a full 64-PAGE, Golden Age style collection!! This issues special Macbre Western theme leads off with The DURANGO KID in “Curse of the Bakala”, as drawn by Joe Certa and John Belfi; followed by the ultimate horror-themed Western character- The HAUNTED HORSEMAN in “The Claws of Horror”, illustrated by Dick Ayers. Then, the great John Buscema illustrates “Wild Bill Pecos Meets The Undertaker”; and The MASKED MARVEL stars in “The Bloodsucker of Banta Gulch”, delineated by Tony Tallarico. Tim Holt as REDMASK takes on “The Ghost of Fort Apache”, drawn by Frank Bolle, MONTE HALE makes “The Gravedigger’s Escape”; LASH LaRUE appears in “Case of the Supernatural, illustrated by Doug Wildey; plus a special, never-before-seen BLACK PHANTOM adventure; “Terror Town”, written by Enrico Teodorani, with art by Anthony Conversano. 8 big stories in all, reprinted from comics originally published by Magazine Enterprises, Charlton, Orbit, Fawcett and others, all reprinted in crisp, clear black & white, using state-of-the-art techniques of reproduction. Standard comic book size; 64 pages saddle-stitched, with a full-color cover a black & white interiors.

Another jumbo-sized, 68-page blockbuster!! This issue opens with the first half of a feature-length BLACK DIAMOND cliffhanger from Black Diamond Western #21, where BD faces off against the villainy of SILK HAT!! Read the thrilling conclusion, “The End Of the Black Diamond” next issue, in Best of the West #71!! Then, The DURANGO KID thunders into action in “The Secret of Durango”, as rendered by Joe Certa & John Belfi, and originally seen in Durango Kid #6. Then, straight out of Masked Rangers Comics #4, from October of 1954, it’s the ORIGIN of The MASKED RANGER in “Mystery of the Masked Ranger”, with art by Jack Abel. Next, it’s Bob Laughlan art on a story previously published in Fawcett’s Monte Hale Western Comics; MONTE HALE And the Hard Luck Ranch. Dick Ayer’s HAUNTED HORSEMAN rides the range in a macabre classic, “Gunfire At Death Cavern”; The DARK RIDER appears in an untitled story drawn by Syd Shores; and REDMASK walks the “Path Of Peril”, from Magazine Enterprises’ Redmask Comics #51, with art by Frank Bolle. The LATIGO KID makes an appearance, in “The Return of Howling Wolf”, sporting art by the great Joe Maneely, and the issue closeswith the first BOW appearance of The CROSS-DRAW KID, as illustrated by Max Elkan in “Six-Gun Justice”, originally printed in October, 1948′s Western Adventures #1. As always, this issue also includes photo inside front & back covers featuring great Western stars like Charles Starrett, Monte Hale & others in repros of classic Western movie still. Color covers with black & white interiors, standard comic book size, saddle-stiiched.This will be the second-to-the-last issue of Best of the West published by AC Comics; next issue’s #71 will be the series’ conclusion.

HISTORIC FINAL ISSUE!! Yes, it’s true, #71 will be the final issue in AC’s historic vintage western reprint anthology, Best of the West- but the title is definitely going out with a bang!! 64 big black & white pages of cowboy comic thrills, starting off with Dick Ayer’s HAUNTED HORSEMAN in “The Beautiful Witch”, a spooky spectacular originally published in Magazine Enterprises’ Ghost Rider #11. Then, it’s M. E.’s The DURANGO KID in “Hangman’s Law”, drawn by Joe Certa and John Belfi. Next, find out if Lev Gleason Pubs’ BLACK DIAMOND will be “Buried Alive”!! A wild Western mystery drawn by William Overgard, originally seen in Black Diamond Western #21, in 1950. Then, it’s film star TIM HOLT as REDMASK in “Death Ride of the Iron Horse”, illustrated by Frank Bolle from Tim Holt #36, in 1953. Then, a surprise guest-feature- The DARK RIDER, in an untitled story as rendered by the great Syd Shores, followed by The LATIGO KID, in “Smoky Showdown”, another classic oater drawn by a past master of the genre, Joe Maneely. Fawcett’s movie cowboy comics feature rings in next with an adventure of MONTE HALE- “Prairie Peddler”, as originally seen in Monte Hale Western #34, in 1948- and drawn by Gil Kane. The MASKED MARVEL appears in “Murder At Dry Gulch!”, illustrated by Tony Tallarico in Gunsmoke Western #11, 1950. Finally, it’s LEMONADE KID in “Terror’s Triggermen!”, as originally seen in Bobby Benson’s B-Bar-B Riders #8, in 1951, and drawn by Bob Powell. In addition, this issue features a never-previously-printed Gil Kane Western illustration, an editorial by publisher Bill Black, and inside cover movie stills featuring Charles Starrett and Jock Mahoney. Standard comic book size, saddle-stitched, with full color covers.

After being dragged through an asteroid field, Leela is found drifting in space with no memory of who she is - that is until Zapp Brannigan claims her as his bride. Plus, in breaking news, Morbo gets his own back-up feature.
name: Lost Our Leela

description: "Hideout in the 25th Century" and "Rome"
name: Apollo's Chariot
How The Jackal Ate The Elephant
Les Trafiquants de la Mer Rouge
Dans les Griffes du Dragon Noir
La Revanche des Fils du Ciel

description:
The hit new MEGA MAN series from Archie Comics continues! Mega Man is about to retire his Mega Buster forever – with Dr. Wily’s schemes defeated, our young hero thinks it’s safe to return to his life as a helper robot. Wrong! Dr. Wily returns with a vengeance, striking back with eight all-new Robot Masters! It’s up to Mega Man to take on the malicious Quick Man and his seven sinister robot brothers, foil Dr. Wily’s insidious schemes, and storm the mad machinist’s castle in a scale so epic you’ll have to see it to believe it! MEGA MAN VOL. 3 collects MEGA MAN #9-12!

Chapter Titles

  • Chapter One: the Next Generation
  • Chapter Two: Conversion Software
  • Chapter Three: System Corruption
  • Chapter Four: Charge of the Light Brigade
name: Vol. 3

volume.name: Mega Man: The Return of Dr. Wily
G.I. Joe A Real American Hero Special Treasury Edition

description:
Ralph is in his dream world, buying beer, when three thugs beat him up, taking his beer. Mr. Foo (owner of Foo's Booze) agrees to teach Ralph how to defend himself. In the first lesson, Ralph is horribly beaten by Foo, but he continues training. Later, Mr. Foo is beaten to death by three thugs in front of Ralph for not paying his protection money. Ralph promises to get revenge. He trains hard for weeks and, at last, invades the gangsters waterfront hideout, and kills them in a terrible fashion. Their boss sics the Crusher, a gigantic, over-muscled mobster, on him. Mr Foo has left the store to Ralph in his will. During a holdup, the Crusher enters and mangles the crook, mistaking him for Ralph. He stomps him into dust and leaves. Later, walking home with beer, he is again beaten by three thugs for his beer.

Back in reality, Dr. Groot injects Ralph with a steroid-like liquid, which he once used on himself.
name: The Crusher

description:
Returning to Earth from the Planet of the Giants, Dunderhead's ship is damaged by a heat-seeking Peace Keeper missile. He gives the order to abandon ship. Earth is in chaos, caused by the evil "Moronic Dicktator", who polluted the airwaves and zombified the kids. Those not affected (Dicktator and his creations) were controlled by "333", a biological computer chip.

Dunderhead's Euckship crashes into the Hollywood sign, but he escapes and lands on his head. The ship's karaoke band, Green Jellÿ, journeys to a nearby tri-level mansion, about to get their big break with Pig'd Nuget's son.

The other captives of the ship, Cowgod, Hotsy Menshot and Dunderhead fight a gigantic battle against T.O.A.H, Orange Krunch and Super Elastic at the base of Dicktator's headquarters.

Angry of the ineptitude of his bumbling creations, he leans out to yell at them when Orange Krunch is rammed into the building and he falls to the ground below.

His creations rebuild his mangled body into Karkuss The Supreme, a mechanical exosuit commanded to serve them for the rest of his eternal life.
